section.title: CHCK_RSLT_ADD_TO_INVISIBLE_WRITTEN
section.programlisting: do { \ tmp = statement; \ if (tmp < 0) {\ PRINT_DEBUG_INFO \ goto clear; \ } \ invisible_written += (size_t)tmp; \ } while(0)

section.title: CHCK_RSLT_ADD_TO_WRITTEN
section.programlisting: do { \ tmp = statement; \ if (tmp < 0) {\ PRINT_DEBUG_INFO \ goto clear; \ } \ written += (size_t)tmp; \ } while(0)

section.title: ft_add_separator()
section.para: Add separator after the current row.

section.title: ft_col_count()
section.para: Get number of columns in the table.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: Number of columns in the table.

section.title: ft_copy_table()
section.para: Copy formatted table.

entry.para: Pointer to formatted table previousley created with ft_create_table. If table is a null pointer, the function returns null.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: The pointer to the new allocated ft_table_t, on success. NULL on error.

section.title: ft_create_table()
section.para: Create formatted table.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: The pointer to the new allocated ft_table_t, on success. NULL on error.

section.title: ft_cur_col()
section.para: Get column number of the current cell.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: Column number of the current cell.

section.title: ft_cur_row()
section.para: Get row number of the current cell.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: Row number of the current cell.

section.title: ft_destroy_table()
section.para: Destroy formatted table.
Destroy formatted table and free all resources allocated during table creation and work with it.

entry.para: Pointer to formatted table previousley created with ft_create_table. If table is a null pointer, the function does nothing.

section.title: ft_erase_range()

para.computeroutput: int ft_erase_range (ft_table_t * table, size_t top_left_row, size_t top_left_col, size_t bottom_right_row, size_t bottom_right_col)

section.para: Erase range of cells.
Range of cells is determined by 2 points (top-left and bottom-right) (both ends are included).

entry.para: Row number of the top left cell in the range.
Column number of the top left cell in the range.
Row number of the bottom right cell in the range.
Column number of the bottom right cell in the range.

section.title: ft_is_empty()
section.para: Check if table is empty.

formalpara.title: Returns
formalpara.para: 1 - table is empty 0 - some data has been inserted

section.title: ft_ln()
section.para: Move current position to the first cell of the next line(row).

note.title: Note
note.para: This function can fail only in case FT_STRATEGY_INSERT adding strategy was set for the table.

para.computeroutput: FT_INTERNAL int ft_nprint (f_conv_context_t * cntx, const char * str, size_t strlen)

int ft_nwprint (f_conv_context_t * cntx, const wchar_t * str, size_t strlen)

section.title: ft_nwrite()

para.computeroutput: int ft_nwrite (ft_table_t * table, size_t count, const char * cell_content, ...)

section.para: Write specified number of strings to the table.
Write specified number of strings to the same number of consecutive cells in the current row.

note.title: Note
note.para: In most cases it is more preferable to use MACRO ft_write instead of ft_nwrite, which is more safe (ft_write automatically counts the number of string arguments and at compile check that all passed arguments are strings).

section.title: ft_nwrite_ln()

para.computeroutput: int ft_nwrite_ln (ft_table_t * table, size_t count, const char * cell_content, ...)

section.para: Write specified number of strings to the table and go to the next line.
Write specified number of strings to the same number of consecutive cells in the current row and move current position to the first cell of the next line(row).

note.title: Note
note.para: In most cases it is more preferable to use MACRO ft_write instead of ft_nwrite, which is more safe (ft_write automatically counts the number of string arguments and at compile check that all passed arguments are strings).

int FT_PRINTF_LN (ft_table_t * table, const char * fmt, ...)

Current cell - cell that will be edited with all modifiing functions (ft_printf, ft_write ...).

entry.para: New row number for the current cell.
New row number for the current cell.

listitem.para: 0: Success; default border style was changed.

listitem.para: 0: Success; default cell property was changed.

section.title: ft_set_memory_funcs()

para.computeroutput: void ft_set_memory_funcs (void *(*)(size_t size) f_malloc, void(*)(void *ptr) f_free)

section.para: Set functions for memory allocation and deallocation to be used instead of standard ones.

entry.para: Pointer to a function for memory allocation that should be used instead of malloc.
Pointer to a function for memory deallocation that should be used instead of free.

note.title: Note
note.para: To return memory allocation/deallocation functions to their standard values set f_malloc and f_free to NULL.

section.title: ft_set_tbl_prop()

para.computeroutput: int ft_set_tbl_prop (ft_table_t * table, uint32_t property, int value)

section.para: Set table property.

entry.para: A pointer to the ft_table_t structure.

listitem.para: 0: Success; default table property was changed.

section.title: ft_set_u8strwid_func()

para.computeroutput: void ft_set_u8strwid_func (int(*)(const void *beg, const void *end, size_t *width) u8strwid)

section.para: Set custom function to compute visible width of UTF-8 string.

libfort internally has a very simple logic to compute visible width of UTF-8 strings. It considers that each codepoint will occupy one position on the terminal in case of monowidth font (some east asians wide and fullwidth characters (see http://www.unicode.org/reports/tr11/tr11-33.html) will occupy 2 positions). This logic is very simple and covers wide range of cases. But obviously there a lot of cases when it is not sufficient. In such cases user should use some external libraries and provide an appropriate function to libfort.

entry.para: User provided function to evaluate width of UTF-8 string ( beg - start of UTF-8 string, end - end of UTF-8 string (not included), width - pointer to the result). If function succeed it should return 0, otherwise some non- zero value. If function returns nonzero value libfort fallbacks to default internal algorithm.

section.title: ft_strerror()
section.para: Return string describing the error_code.

entry.para: Error code returned by the library.

section.title: ft_to_string()
section.para: Convert table to string representation.
ft_table_t has ownership of the returned pointer. So there is no need to free it. To take ownership user should explicitly copy the returned string with strdup or similar functions.

listitem.para: The pointer to the string representation of formatted table, on success.
